articles.headline: Inside a Powerful Silicon Valley Charity, a Toxic Culture Festered
articles.snippet: The Silicon Valley Community Foundation, whose wealthy donors include Mark Zuckerberg, Reed Hastings and Jack Dorsey, is facing scrutiny about the actions of its top two executives.
articles.abstract: The Silicon Valley Community Foundation, whose wealthy donors include Mark Zuckerberg, Reed Hastings and Jack Dorsey, is facing scrutiny about the actions of its top two executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Silicon Valley technology executives have amassed enormous fortunes in recent years, one relatively obscure group — the Silicon Valley Community Foundation — has emerged as the local charity of choice.

articles.headline: Trump Promises Lower Drug Prices, but Drops Populist Solutions
articles.snippet: The president said he would promote more competition among pharmaceutical companies, but didn’t call for Medicare to directly negotiate lower prices or consumers to be able to import low-cost drugs.
articles.abstract: The president said he would promote more competition among pharmaceutical companies, but didn’t call for Medicare to directly negotiate lower prices or consumers to be able to import low-cost drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump vowed on Friday to “bring soaring drug prices back down to earth” by promoting competition among pharmaceutical companies, and he suggested that the government could require drugmakers to disclose prices in their ubiquitous television advertising.

articles.headline: How a Web of Slip-and-Fall Cases Puts a New Spin on an Old-Fashioned Scheme
articles.snippet: A federal case in Manhattan involving what the authorities say was a long-running fraud sheds light on the untamed nature of the litigation-finance business.
articles.abstract: A federal case in Manhattan involving what the authorities say was a long-running fraud sheds light on the untamed nature of the litigation-finance business.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounded like an old school slip-and-fall scam with a modern-day financial twist.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: At Toys ‘R’ Us, a $200 Million Debt Problem Could Lead to $348 Million in Fees
articles.snippet: The retailer’s fall shows how lucrative bankruptcy can be for lawyers and other professionals, while creditors and workers are often left with little.
articles.abstract: The retailer’s fall shows how lucrative bankruptcy can be for lawyers and other professionals, while creditors and workers are often left with little.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, Toys “R” Us, struggling in the face of competition, wanted to refinance about $200 million in debt.

articles.headline: What Meghan Markle Means to Black Britons
articles.snippet: Black Londoners like Tshego Lengolo, 11, suddenly have a reason to tune in to Britain’s royal family: They can see a version of themselves in the woman Prince Harry is set to marry.
articles.abstract: Black Londoners like Tshego Lengolo, 11, suddenly have a reason to tune in to Britain’s royal family: They can see a version of themselves in the woman Prince Harry is set to marry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the days to come, anyone wishing to criticize Meghan Markle, the American actress set to marry into Britain’s royal family, will have to contend with Tshego Lengolo, an 11-year-old black girl and newly minted monarchist.

articles.headline: These 95 Apartments Promised Affordable Rent in San Francisco. Then 6,580 People Applied.
articles.snippet: The nation’s housing policy for the poor can feel like a giant lottery. Sometimes it actually is a lottery.
articles.abstract: The nation’s housing policy for the poor can feel like a giant lottery. Sometimes it actually is a lottery.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For $1,200 a month, Patricia Torres and her family were renting a bedroom, a share of time in the bathroom, one vegetable drawer and one shelf in the fridge, and two cupboards over the stove. They rented not so much a home as a fraction of one.
articles.byline: By Emily Badger and Jim Wilson

articles.headline: His College Knew of His Despair. His Parents Didn’t, Until It Was Too Late.
articles.snippet: Hamilton College knew that one of its students was in deep distress before he killed himself. His parents believe they should have been told.
articles.abstract: Hamilton College knew that one of its students was in deep distress before he killed himself. His parents believe they should have been told.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLINTON, N.Y. — In the days after her son Graham hanged himself in his dormitory room at Hamilton College, Gina Burton went about settling his affairs in a blur of efficiency, her grief tinged with a nagging sense that something did not add up.

articles.headline: Clashing Views on Iran Reflect a New Balance of Power in the Cabinet
articles.snippet: John R. Bolton, the new national security adviser, is on the rise, and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis appears more isolated. The new secretary of state, Mike Pompeo, may be the man in the middle.
articles.abstract: John R. Bolton, the new national security adviser, is on the rise, and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis appears more isolated. The new secretary of state, Mike Pompeo, may be the man in the middle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five days before President Trump pulled out of what he called the “horrible” Iran nuclear deal, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told diplomats from Britain, France and Germany that he believed the pact could still be saved.

articles.headline: Federal Tax Cuts Leave States in a Bind
articles.snippet: The federal tax law had the unintended effect of giving states a tax windfall. Now, states must weigh whether to spend the money or give it back to residents.
articles.abstract: The federal tax law had the unintended effect of giving states a tax windfall. Now, states must weigh whether to spend the money or give it back to residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal tax overhaul cut taxes for millions of American families and businesses. But the law also had an unintended effect: raising the state-tax bite in nearly every state that has an income tax.

articles.headline: Education Department Unwinds Unit Investigating Fraud at For-Profits
articles.snippet: A team of lawyers and investigators had looked into advertising at big colleges. Now it mostly processes student loan forgiveness applications.
articles.abstract: A team of lawyers and investigators had looked into advertising at big colleges. Now it mostly processes student loan forgiveness applications.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of a special team at the Education Department that had been investigating widespread abuses by for-profit colleges have been marginalized, reassigned or instructed to focus on other matters, according to current and former employees.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory, Erica L. Green and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Deadly Convenience: Keyless Cars and Their Carbon Monoxide Toll
articles.snippet: Weaned from using a key, drivers have left cars running in garages, spewing exhaust into homes. Despite years of deaths, regulatory action has lagged.
articles.abstract: Weaned from using a key, drivers have left cars running in garages, spewing exhaust into homes. Despite years of deaths, regulatory action has lagged.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems like a common convenience in a digital age: a car that can be powered on and off with the push of a button, rather than the mechanical turning of a key. But it is a convenience that can have a deadly effect.
articles.byline: By David Jeans and Majlie De Puy Kamp

articles.headline: In About-Face on Trade, Trump Vows to Protect ZTE Jobs in China
articles.snippet: The company, which was barred from using American components, said it had halted “major operating activities.”
articles.abstract: The company, which was barred from using American components, said it had halted “major operating activities.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As China and the United States go toe-to-toe on trade and maneuver ahead of a historic North Korea meeting next month, an unlikely obstacle has emerged: a second-tier Chinese electronics maker, ZTE.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: With Demise of Nuclear Deal, Iran’s Foes See an Opportunity. Others See Risk of War.
articles.snippet: Iran has proved adept at exploiting upheavals in the Middle East to deter enemies and spread its influence. Now President Trump and American allies in the region want to turn back the clock.
articles.abstract: Iran has proved adept at exploiting upheavals in the Middle East to deter enemies and spread its influence. Now President Trump and American allies in the region want to turn back the clock.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After the United States toppled Iraq’s dictatorship in 2003, Iran sent arms to militias and backed political parties there, bringing Iraq into its orbit.

articles.headline: Disarray Plagues U.S. Companies’ Efforts to Win Tariff Exemptions
articles.snippet: The metal tariffs were supposed to protect manufacturers. But they are also delaying investment, expansion and hiring until companies know where they stand.
articles.abstract: The metal tariffs were supposed to protect manufacturers. But they are also delaying investment, expansion and hiring until companies know where they stand.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For several weeks this spring, a handful of employees at a Texas steel manufacturer stopped producing pipes used to drill thousands of feet below the earth’s surface to concentrate full time on another task: trying to win the company an exemption from President Trump’s metals tariffs.

articles.headline: Why Traditional TV Is in Trouble
articles.snippet: Dropping ratings, especially among young people, and more viewing options mean broadcast TV is in a precarious position as it pitches itself to advertisers.
articles.abstract: Dropping ratings, especially among young people, and more viewing options mean broadcast TV is in a precarious position as it pitches itself to advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Television networks will draw hordes of advertisers to New York City this week for their annual bonanza of presentations and parties, a decades-old tradition known as the upfronts that is meant to dazzle marketers and loosen their purse strings.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and John Koblin

articles.headline: Reality TV Kingpin Mike Darnell Wants One More Hit
articles.snippet: But it’s not as easy as it used to be. “The viewer is desensitized,” Mr. Darnell says. “It’s much, much, much harder to get people’s attention.”
articles.abstract: But it’s not as easy as it used to be. “The viewer is desensitized,” Mr. Darnell says. “It’s much, much, much harder to get people’s attention.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — If he really wanted to, Mike Darnell could probably cast himself in one of the many shows he oversees as the head of unscripted programming at Warner Bros.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Faces Regulatory Fight on Its Home Turf
articles.snippet: A ballot measure brought by a real estate developer, a former C.I.A. analyst and a finance executive would create tough data privacy laws.
articles.abstract: A ballot measure brought by a real estate developer, a former C.I.A. analyst and a finance executive would create tough data privacy laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The staging ground for one of the biggest regulatory fights facing the technology industry is far removed from Washington or Brussels, tucked into an alley next to a wine and cheese shop about 30 miles from Silicon Valley.

articles.headline: Israel Feels Pride but Senses Peril as U.S. Moves Embassy
articles.snippet: On the eve of its 70th anniversary, Israel is torn by forces within and without. For all the successes, one historian said, “the future is very bleak.”
articles.abstract: On the eve of its 70th anniversary, Israel is torn by forces within and without. For all the successes, one historian said, “the future is very bleak.”
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When Israel declared its independence in 1948, President Harry Truman rushed to recognize it. He took just 11 minutes, and Israelis, about to go to war to defend their infant state, were euphoric.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Ruling Favors Sports Betting
articles.snippet: The case concerned New Jersey, but it has implications for other states eager to allow and tax sports gambling. Americans are estimated to annually place $150 billion in illegal wagers on sports.
articles.abstract: The case concerned New Jersey, but it has implications for other states eager to allow and tax sports gambling. Americans are estimated to annually place $150 billion in illegal wagers on sports.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court struck down a 1992 federal law on Monday that effectively banned commercial sports betting in most states, opening the door to legalizing the estimated $150 billion in illegal wagers on professional and amateur sports that Americans make every year.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: Trump Shifts From Trade War Threats to Concessions in Rebuff to Hard-Liners
articles.snippet: The shift by the American president could ease tensions ahead of a visit to Washington by Liu He, a vice premier in the Beijing government.
articles.abstract: The shift by the American president could ease tensions ahead of a visit to Washington by Liu He, a vice premier in the Beijing government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s recent threat to impose tariffs on as much as $150 billion worth of Chinese goods appeared to be the first volley in what looked like a full-scale trade war with the nation’s greatest economic adversary. Now, suddenly, Mr. Trump seems ready to make peace.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Mark Landler and Keith Bradsher
